sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: I’m Jihad Al Sayed, and today we’re talking about linear independence — one of the most important concepts in linear algebra. It tells us whether vectors bring unique value or just repeat what others are already doing.

sections.title: What Is Linear Independence?
sections.content: A set of vectors is linearly independent if no vector in the set can be written as a combination of the others. If one can, the set is dependent.

sections.title: Test for Linear Independence
sections.math: A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \\ 7 & 8 & 9\end{bmatrix} \Rightarrow \text{Check if Ax = 0 has only the trivial solution}

sections.title: Recap
sections.content: We defined linear independence, saw how to test it using matrices, and walked through examples. This concept is foundational for vector spaces, basis sets, and dimensionality in ML and data science.
